Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement to sit where it pleases - "waiting my turn" -, while the Dutch continue with their conviction that "anyone who wants to definitely should". This underlying cacoshism attracts comparisons with Asians.
I don't think that's without comparison either, yet these observations are very interesting.

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well suited to Polish director Agnieszka Holland’s style.
Holland initially appears to be positioning her movie as an attack against British colonialism; indeed Finn’s family arrives on Parker’s ship by training a group of Māori warriors known only as “Dandy.”

While credited as a Tom and Jerry cartoon, this is not the cat-and-mouse team but an earlier Mutt-and-Jeff rip-off featuring them going about to survive in today's turbulent economy. In the end, they channel their problems over into other aspects of their lives until they are engulfed in payback wrath by another group of stick-up victims. Alan Gordon makes his screen debut with Jeff Bridges (before he became a star), and it was directed by George Pal

Snow White is in my opinion a bad movie on an artistic point of view. The plot is pretty much foreseeable, the characters are stereotypes, the editing too. But it’s got vibes that pulls you in and reminds me of your favorite Disney princesses as Pocahontas and Mulan. And voila, Brother Bear is good! If you’re looking for a serious animated movie, that has positive messages found in traditional folklore then this one’s right up your alley

What is left of Planet Earth is populated by a few poor and starving rag-tag survivors. They must eat bugs and insects, or whatever they can find. The wealthy fliers have long since left Planet Earth, for adventures in the countless empires that make up the Hunting Worlds. STOCKART: Space Toledo "The Astronaut Station 'The League of Families' (Affectionately. known among a certain affected crowd as "Extra-Terrestrial Dev

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is clearly an attempt to catch the wave of martial arts popularity just as that genre was starting to take off with films like Enter The Dragon. It is a basic revenge plot and it is acted well enough but beside a couple of fun action scenes this movie quickly becomes dull and tedius.
